captions.text:
When YouTube started demonetising basically
any usage of &quot;fudge&quot;, I really thought I could cope.

I thought the methadone of saying things
like &quot;noob gobbles&quot; instead would tide me over.

But there really are times when
nothing will do the job but a good hard &quot;flip&quot;.

So here&#39;s the deal, I&#39;m going to start
saying &quot;flim flam&quot; again, but you&#39;ll only hear it

uncensored in the subscribers version, cause
the extra money means we can tell YouTube to stick

their demonetisation up there - &quot;Nostril!&quot;.
As well as meaning you don&#39;t have to put up with

&quot;dastardly&quot;. Sponsors. So head
over to Patreon and &quot;jollywell&quot;. Sign up.
[Intro Music]

In the last few weeks I could have been
reviewing the fucking Rapture and someone in the comments

would still have said &quot;Yeah yeah, you
beheld a great beast with blasphemous names on each

of its seven heads, when
are you gonna do Armored Core 6?&quot;

Half of them going &quot;Ooh,
it&#39;s by From Software and it&#39;s

basically a Souls-like
with giant robots, you&#39;ll love it!&quot;

And the other half going &quot;Ooh, it&#39;s by From
Software and it&#39;s absolutely nothing like a Souls-like

but you keep saying you&#39;re sick of
them and it&#39;s got giant robots, you&#39;ll love it!&quot;

I did try Armored Core 6 when it
came out, but bounced off at first in

much the same way the entire giant
mecha concept bounces off common sense.

I guess that&#39;s kinda why I have
trouble getting into giant robot stuff.

If it&#39;s trying to take itself seriously, I
keep getting distracted by nagging thoughts, like

&quot;Why would you ever rely upon giant robots
with laser swords piloted by one dude rather than use

the exact same
materials to make, say, 500 tanks?&quot;

that could do more than
one job at a time and don&#39;t require

centuries of high level robotics
research to ensure they don&#39;t fall over.

But the constant requests and the
brief gap in the release schedule wore me down.

So I went back to AC6, that&#39;s Armored Core
not Assassin&#39;s Creed, or Animal Crossing, or Ashurons

Call, or Ace Combat or
Assetto Corsa or Astral Chain-
Jesus, what is it with video games and AC?

Are they trying to subliminally inform the
building manager that the central heating needs fixing?

And fine, I admit it, once I strapped
myself down and forced myself to give it more time, I

eventually got into Alice Cooper
6, although not because it&#39;s Souls-like.

It&#39;s only like Dark Souls in that there&#39;s a
focus on one-on-one boss fights, an estus flask-esque

healing system, difficult combat that
involves a lot of running around in circles,

and a choice of endings that comes down to
whether or not you want to light yourself on fire.

People will call
anything Souls-like these days, it&#39;s

never been a
well-defined genre at the best of times.

Ooh Sonic, the hedgehogs are Souls-like,
cause the rings are Estus and the checkpoints are

bonfires, and you can summon a
fox with two buttholes as a support NPC.

Anyway, in Armored Core 6, you&#39;re a mercenary
who&#39;s been brought to a planet full of potentially

hugely destructive magic, goo that a
bunch of corporations are fighting over,

a premise that
reminded me of Lost Planet a lot, in

that I didn&#39;t give much
of a shit about that either.

Initially the plot felt like little more
than a slim excuse for making giant robots smack each

other about, and there was a lot about
the game I found intimidating on my first shake.

Perhaps it was the first mission in which the
game goes &quot;Right, here&#39;s how you move, here&#39;s how you

fire your weapons, got all that, now kill
this giant flying robot death monster that wants to

destroy you with a
ferocity seen only in a desperately

undernourished spider trapped in a
bell jar with a miniature bacon sandwich.&quot;

And obviously I got
stomped into a carelessly dismantled

Meccano project, but over
multiple attempts I felt out the workings.

I soon learned that trying to be clever by
hiding amid buildings, moving in out of range, etc.

would result in the
boss going &quot;Hmm, interesting.&quot;
Counterpoint, white hot stream of pitiless death.

But after several tries I managed to
sustain consistent damage for long enough to fill the

mysterious orange bar under his health, at
which point his trousers dropped around his ankles and I

did some serious damage to
him while he was pulling them back up.

Aha! This isn&#39;t Giant Robot
Dark Souls, it&#39;s Giant Robot Sekiro.

Except instead of perfects parrying over and
over again you just shoot things a lot with a gun.

The other thing I found intimidating was going
into the parts shop as the game would spread a load
of engine parts across the floor with a thousand

stats attached and
impatiently go &quot;What do you want?&quot;

Cigarette poking from mouth
like an extra in a Billy Joel video.

But again, with time I figured out the
best approach, construct an in-betweeny all-rounder

mechanical evening suit that had decent
stats, avoiding the tiny spindly kitchen utensil legs for

the super light fast builds, and the
giant chunky flared trousers for the heavy tanks.

And then pile as much raw firepower onto my
shoulders as I could without my legs going bandy.

And after that I stuck to the strategy of
running in circles around the target holding down all the

fire buttons until the
pants fall off, meter was full, and

then speeding in for a 1-2
laser sword wall up to the perineum.

And pursuing this philosophy I found Anton
Chekov 6 to be a game of very inconsistent difficulty.

The regular enemies slow you down as much as
the little dotted lines around the doors of an advent

calendar, but every now and
again there&#39;s an absolute roadblock

of a boss fight that I&#39;d have
to hammer away at for half an hour.

I appreciate the game game intends you to mix up
your build to suit the situation as there&#39;s a special

option on the game over menu for making a
quick pit stop to switch to a nicer head and bigger

trousers, but I
powerfully couldn&#39;t be arsed to do that.
And who needs roomier trousers without an arse?

Also, sometimes the game&#39;s nice enough to
checkpoint you at the start of the boss and sometimes for

every attempt you&#39;ve got
to plough through two rooms in a

cinematic that wasn&#39;t
terribly interesting the first time.

And while we&#39;re on the subject, I guess the
story&#39;s about as effective as one can get considering

every NPC has a faceless voice on a radio and
could conceivably be all the same dude putting on a

variety of silly accents, but it was hard to
get invested early on before the personalities had

properly crystallised, especially with the
mission-based structuring that is always the death of

pacing and flow, because the
game has to stop every five minutes to ask

permission to continue, and that
tends to put me in a philosophical mood.
Do I want to continue?
Boy, that&#39;s a hell of a question.

I mean, I&#39;d appreciate the rest, but if I miss
another Thanksgiving I&#39;ll never hear the end of it.
Oh, you meant in the game!

Nevertheless, as I say I did
find myself getting into Andrew Carnegie

Six, and I think at the end of
the day it came down to sheer spectacle.

It&#39;s sometimes hard to get a
sense of the scale you&#39;re supposed to be at.

Sure, you can see little human-sized vehicles
and stairwells and occasionally walk down a nine-lane

highway like it&#39;s a
jogging track, but you could just be

a dude in a model village
cosplaying as a kitchen island.

So to compensate, the environments get
even crazier with scale, which makes the notion that

regular-sized humans use the space even
more ridiculous, because there are corridors and

ventilation shafts that a person couldn&#39;t walk
across without a pack mule and a week&#39;s provisions.

But gosh darn it, at the end of the day, all
gameplay, interface and story nickels aside, it is

pretty fun and exciting to flit around an
entire ruined city, dodging streams of explosions while

keeping a bead on a target against the
backdrop of a colossal industrial structure that makes you

feel like an ant
exploring a disused barbecue grill.

And hey, 500 tanks couldn&#39;t do that, or
indeed navigate the Birmingham one-way system.
